data.title: Stand Up and Cheer! (1934)
data.meta_description: President Franklin Roosevelt appoints a theatrical producer as the new Secretary of Amusement in order to cheer up an American public still suffering through the Depression. The new secretary soon runs afoul of political lobbyists out to destroy his department.
data.text:
I was so hoping to love this film - there are many other variety musicals from this period that I've enjoyed. But with this as an example, I'd say Fox just wasn't as good at musicals as Warner Brothers or RKO at this time. The story was of a famous Broadway producer being appointed by the president as the Secretary of Amusement in order to jolly America out of the Depression. It had variety numbers just sort of starting and stopping in between scenes of Warner Baxter chewing the scenery.

A couple of moments that will stay with me though: First was Shirley Temple featured in a big production number of Baby Take a Bow. This is Shirley of the…

Well, this was... strange. I wondered at first if this was Shirley Temple's first movie, because it clearly wasn't meant as a vehicle for her -- she's in it for a grand total of MAYBE five minutes -- but it looks like she was in other things before this, so hadonno. Good things first: the final number is really entertaining, very hopeful and optimistic, the love ballad is very pretty and gorgeously sung, and when Shirley is in the movie, she doesn't have any terrible or uber precocious dialogue, so she's a pretty cute little kid. However, the rest of this move is CRAZY. The plot is really scattered and abrupt, and it's interrupted by what I must assume are…
